issues.description: The problem statement (including the UML) requires a method addGuestStudents(int, String) — i.e., two parameters (number of new guest students and a reason). The solution implementation provides addGuestStudents(int) with only a single int parameter and no reason. This signature mismatch means students following the specification (or tests generated from it) will expect a two-parameter method but the reference implementation uses a different signature, causing confusion and likely failing signature-based tests.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the solution and template match the problem specification. Update the method signature in the solution (and add the matching stub in the template) to: public void addGuestStudents(int numberOfNewGuestStudents, String reason) { this.numberOfGuestStudents += numberOfNewGuestStudents; /* optionally use reason (e.g., log or store) */ } Alternatively, if the reason parameter was intentionally omitted, update the problem statement and UML to specify addGuestStudents(int) to avoid the mismatch.

issues.description: The problem statement (and UML) require a method addGuestStudents(int, String) that accepts a number of new guest students and a String 'reason'. The solution implementation provides addGuestStudents(int numberOfNewGuestStudents) — the String parameter is missing. This is an unintended semantic mismatch in the method signature/parameters: students reading the problem/template will expect to implement or call addGuestStudents with two parameters (int and String), but the reference solution only defines a one-parameter version, which creates confusion about the expected API and its usage.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the method signature across artifacts. Either (A) update the solution to match the problem/template by changing the method signature to: public void addGuestStudents(int numberOfNewGuestStudents, String reason) { this.numberOfGuestStudents += numberOfNewGuestStudents; /* optionally handle or log reason */ } or (B) if the reason parameter is unnecessary, update the problem statement and UML to specify addGuestStudents(int) only. Option A is recommended to preserve the stated requirement: accept the reason parameter (it can be stored, logged, or left unused but present) so students see a consistent API.
